After wkiob, Mr. BTJCKSTONE'S papular Coewdy of

SINGLE L I F E .
A s tbe Comedy of ' MARRIED L I F E * attempted to illustrate a few of
the humour* of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author of • SINGLE L I F E '
i n going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters 'LOVERS
ALL,* hopes to be equally successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickerings as well as the most loyal one of • The United States.*

T h e C o m e d y of ' SINGLE LIFE <' is p u b l i s h e d i n Webster's e d i t i o n of t h e " N a t i o n a l
Acting Drama," a n d m a y be h a d i n t h e T h e a t r e a n d of a l l Booksellers,—prioe Is.
After which, Mr. BtCKSTONE'S oopular Comedy of

SINGLE LIFE.

As the Comedy of * MARRIED LIFE ' attempted to illustrate a few of
the humours of the State Matrimonial, and interest an Audience without
the introduction of any Lovers whatever; the author of • SIN CrUB LIFE*
In going to the opposite extreme and making his Characters * LOVERS
ALL,' hopes to be equally successful in pourtraying some of the vagaries
of Courtship, and showing that the democratic region of celibacy has its
bickerings as well as the most loyal one of • The United States.*

O P I N I O N S of the PUBLIC P R E S S .
• ' Money!'—a new comedy, by Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer,
Bart , w u played here for the first time last night The house
was crowded in every part, and the applause loud and continuous: there were at intervals sounds of dissent m.ngling in
the storm of approbation ; bat to us they appeared to em mate
from the malice of part) feeling, rather than from the conscientious exercise of free judgment. The opposition was, certainly,
-i.st triumphantly overwhelmed by the most enthusiastic
•pplause. The piece will doubtless run the season."—Morning Herald, tfcdnesday, Dee. 9.
" The merit of the piece really lay in the construction of some
of the seenes, where a great number of persons could be combined with effect The reading of the will, the Hustle of the
club-room, with the dovetailing of the sieeches of 'he various
personages on the stage, evinced talent, and that in a •itticult
part of dtamatie construction. To this was the favourable
reception of the drasaa greatly to !>•• attributed, and also to
the termination of the story. As far as .leootatimi \s concerned,
we do not believe the Hay-market boards were ever so adorned
before
T h . acene at 'Croekford's, with the little tables,
Kvelyrie room hung w.th pictures, and surrounded with
.tatties, and opening on a diaing-roin, were very b autiful,
Webster announced the repetition of the piece with loud
applause."—71W Timta, fVedneeday, Dee. 9.
" The new comedy of' Monty !' was a happy and triumphant
answer to all that eloquence and ingenuity which have so long
maintained the hopelessness of expeotiog, in the present day,
anything like a revival of the «i>irit of the old English comedy
of manners and character. Trie comic muse must not yet
despair; and we must not yet flatter ourselves that we have
been thoroughly taught, by either gaiety or gravity, the actor
or the schoolmaster. Sir ftdward Bulwer has shown how rich
are still die comic materials of the time, to a shrewd and exact
observer; aud that fashionable life has nothing left of its
egotism and hollowneaa since my Lord Fopptngton ' sapped
his vital*.* It would be impossible to praise too highly the
appointments of this comedy, and the manner in which it has
been placed on the atage. Eveivtlung was real, and nothing
less splendid than it should hate been. The house of Evelyn
was a pas-feet picture of gorgeous taste ; and the club scene,
with its crowds of well-dressed members and niceties of arrangement and furniture, would no doubt be recognised by
»any among th* audience."—Morning Ckromlce, Wednesday,

Dec- 9.
" ' Monty !' was produced at this theatre last night, with all
th* aid* of entirely new scenery, dresses, furniture, and appurtenances. It is but fair to notice th* magnificent manner in
which Mr. Webster has put it on the atage N*w furniture did
not alone appear in the play-bills ; had the most fashionable
upholsterer been consulted, taste and splendour could not have
shone more conspicuously. The comedy was justly molt successful. The dialogue is well suited to each parson in the
drama There is no double plot to perplex, no inharmonious—
no incongruous shifting of time or place; tha wholes is
finely kept together, ihe main story being constantly before th*
mind's eye. At the fall of the curtain the applause was loud,
long-continued, and general. Tb« comedy will doubtless bear
the management well up till the close of the season. *—Morning
Advertiser, Wednesday, Dee. 9.
•* Sir E. L. Bulwer's ' Money!' after being loag promised,
was at length paid, and the public went after it in such uroads
a* to create quite a run u on the Hay-Market bank. It had
b e e . elaborately prepared, and was cast with great strength
and propriety. In fact, a good title, good management, and a
rood company have dose their best to support the original
merits of th* author, In the article of ' Money!' it was predicted that he had brought forward ' something that was sure
to go t and go it did most heartily, to the apparent content of
author, actors, and audience. We record its appearance,
therefore, as decidedly and unequivocally successful. It was
annouaced for every evening until further notice, and was
in all respects so successful that we suppose it will carry
through the season. Its illustration by scenery and appointments is costly, appropriate, and elegant."—Morning Poll,
Dee. 9
'
" * Money /' was produced here last evening, and with merited
success A play that has had the advantage of every character
being ably tiled. It would be invidious, indeed, to name any
one in particular, all so ably enacted their respective parts.
Mr Webster announced its repetition every evening, amidst the
most enthusiastic applause of a crowded and fashionable
audience. The play has been produced with great tas « and
splendour in t h . scenic department, and as regards the appointment* generally-"—The Courier. Wednesday, Dec. 9.
" ' T h . situations are very effecti*., and the acting throughout was such as to give great support to the play, and nothing
could be more unequivocal than th* success of the piece."—
(Mate, Wednesday, Dee. 9.
'• * Money t was represented at this Theatre. n»e hows*
was crowded in every part, and the applause throughout t b .
piece was laud and continuous. It was in all respects so «uroeeaful that we suppose it will carry through the season We
hav* to repeat that th* manager has bestowed his best labour
upon its production. Its illustration by scenery and appointmerits is costly, appropriate, and elegant'—Observer, Dec. 13.
" The long-promised Comedv by Sir Edward Lyiton Bolwer was played at the Hay-Market.Theatre with remarkable
•access. Its merit is, that, (com the opening to the closing
scene, til* writer's intention is never lost sight of. It is a design worthy of the genius of Comedy in its best direction. The
characters are very humourous, all vety carefully finished, and
not less broadlv. ioroibly, and naturally marked, than they are
clearly and strikingly distinguished from each other."—Examiner, Dec. i8.

" Sir E. L. Bulwer has treated' Money !' with some master!y
rouj.mgs ot vast scenic effect,—witness the will aud t h . club •
fdifference,
ouse—bis characters on the whole maintaining their genarte
whilst the pathos is in parts deep and intense.".-.
Era, Sunday, Dec. IS.
" The cast of the comedy embraced the whole strength of t h .
company, and all the performers acted with energy, and *» evident desire to carry the play through with success. The situations are g.,jd, and the comedy may be ranked with some af
our best modern productions. The getting-up of the comedy
is excellent We have never seen anything half so well d o n .
on the Hay-Market stage. The appointments are first-rate,
and no expe ise has been spared to render the comedy attractive."—TV Aye, Dec. 13.
" T h e cle.ar toting, the superb scenery and appointment*-,
and the finished manner in which the play is placed on t h .
stage, eotitrih ited materially to its success Nothing could b .
better Th a pin was received with great applause, and is
likely to run through the. season."—Athtneeum, Saturday.
B*e.. 12.
^
Nothing can exceed the care with which the play has been
pt odaoed. the scenery is euremely ingenious, and occasionally beautifu'; and the performers are thoroughly versed in
their respect, ire characters. In short, all persons in any way
o inected with the comedy have acquitted themselves to perfection."— -Argus, Dec. II.
" The coitedy of' Money!' by Sir E. L. Bal.ver, has been
brought upon the boards with all that strength of east and propriety of scenic adj.in.-l which we presume io person will dispute as a continuous evidence of Mr •Vebster's eiterprise,
talent, snd industry as a manager. He has i^.ven. we say, the
whole might of his accessory aid to the eh ne.ly, and it has succeeded and i« popular"—Uourt Journal, Dec. 12.
" Sir Eiward Lytton Bulwer s comely wis it last produced,
with deeded success. It is a performance which will of itself
com mind success. The scenery and dresses are nearly faultless—th* first gorge us and costly, and the second accurate
transfers from existing westward ongiiials."—Life in London,
Dec. 13.
•' Sir Edward Lytton Bulwer's comedy is certainly the best
modern comedy (hatha* been produced for me nv \ ears. Altogether it is one of very great merit j the interest throughout is
most powerfully sustained; from the first act to the last, the
attention is constantly excited by some new incident. T h .
language too is extremely good; it abounds in point, and which
falling off without any seeming effect, tells with the beat effect.
We need scarcely say that the play was in the highest degree
successful, and that it wilt rival the £e*e Chase in its career.
With regard to the acting, we have also to speak in term, of
high praise The scenery is beautifully painted, and every
scene is laid out to give an exact rspreaentation of an elegant
room with all its luxuries and extravagant appendages. T h e
interior ot Cro<-kford's Club is admirably done, and elicited
much applause fom its splendour."—Magnet, Dee. 14.
" Sir £. L. Bulwer s play of ' Money !' was produced at this
theatre, with a cast and in a style that did great credit to the
theatre. The genuine power of this performance belongs to
an ancient, recognised, and high order of the comic. The
power of seizing the characters and manners of the age, snd
holding the mirror up to society; and that, too, after it has so
long been asserted that the progress of civilisation and destroyed the materials for such a purpose. Sir Edward Lytton
Bulwer has shown us, on the contrary, that life is yet full of
varieties sufficient!) marked for th.most effective uses of the
drama,—that there ara men, distinct from the surrounding
herd, whose individualities are admirably fit for the stagehand that the-e ire * anes in the commonest streets through
which we daily > alk, as amusing and rich as were offered to
Goiigreve, or Karqubar, or aay of the elder dramatists, before
tne social system was macadamised into a rather general level.
His figures stand out well from the mass. A better acting, or
better acted n'a lias not been brought out in our time, and we
remember Joan BulL It often, by its sparkling allusions,
recalled The School for Scandal to our minds, and the drop
scene certainly lell upon every act amidst bursts of applause to
the ski!! displayed in the construction of these pauses, giving
enic ieffect and interest which could not be imnroved.
each a scenic
Literary &az<tte, Saturday December 12.
Monty !' was brought out at the Hay-Market under every
possible advantage. The actors to a man were zealous in tha
cause, and both scene-painter and manager had done their
beat to give splendour and completeness to the miseenteene—which is as supeib and brilliant as Oovent Garden ever wifrnessed, and surpasses in power of illusion all former doings of
the Haymarket stage. To orown all, the play was successful;
the most fastidiouslaughed, and the less critical portion of the
audience seemed delighted equally with the fun and the sentiment. It is pointed and clever. Some bustling scenes of
broad farce are intermixed with a due quantity of sentimental
speeches , and the stage situations ar* as effectively ludicrous
as any that BOC«STOH» ever oeatnteeV- The scenes at the
club were rapitally managed; and that where ivelyn is
pigeoned bj Dudley Smooth is highly amusing and life-tike."—
Spectator, Dec. 12.
" Sir B. L. Bulwer's comedy of ' Money !' and the unmixed
enthusiasm with which it has been received may be accepted as
a proof that it is skilfully constructed. This drama is a
work of very t i.tsiderable merit. We have not for many sears
seen a comely brought out with so much aocuracy and harmony in ihe uerftils, au I presenting so oompieta an ensemble.
Theacut 4 » i - idmirabie throughout, and it would be exceedingly dtmcult to detect a single fault. The costume and
scenery of the play deserve especial admiration. The %_
penditura that has been bestowed upon this production will^T
amply repaid by its success."—Atlas, Satunlay, Dec. 10.
